elements.content: Crystalline KTiOPO4 (KTP), an inorganic nonlinear optical material with a waveguide figure-of-merit that is twice that of other mixed-metal oxides, contains helical chains of TiO4/2O2/2 octahedra in which a long, short Ti−O bond motif results in a net c-directed polarization. The alternating long and short Ti−O bonds that occur along these chains are the major contributors to the large nonlinear optic and electrooptic coefficients. Analogous chains have been constructed using dichromate [Cr2O7]2-anions and [M(py)4]2+ (M = Cu, Zn) cations; these new transition metal oxides crystallize in the same space group as KTP. Crystal data for Cu(py)4Cr2O7:  orthorhombic, space group Pna21 (No. 33), with a = 15.941(7) Å, b = 16.324(3) Å, c = 8.857(2) Å, and Z = 4; for Zn(py)4Cr2O7, orthorhombic, space group Pna21 (No. 33), with a = 16.503(1) Å, b = 16.005(1) Å, c = 8.8130(5) Å, and Z = 4; for Cd(py)4Cr2O7, monoclinic, space group C2/c (No. 15), with a = 14.8034(9) Å, b = 11.1847(7) Å, c = 15.788(1) Å, β = 110.023(1)°, and Z = 4.

The alternating long and short Ti-O bonds that occur along these chains are the major contributors to the large nonlinear optic and electrooptic coefficients. Crystal data for Cu(py)4Cr2O7: orthorhombic, space group Pna21 (No. 33), with a = 15.941(7) Å, b = 16.324(3) Å, c = 8.857(2) Å, and Z = 4; for Zn(py)4Cr2O7, orthorhombic, space group Pna21 (No. 33), with a = 16.503(1) Å, b = 16.005(1) Å, c = 8.8130(5) Å, and Z = 4; for Cd(py)4Cr2O7, monoclinic, space group C2/c (No. 15), with a = 14.8034(9) Å, b = 11.1847(7) Å, c = 15.788(1) Å, β = 110.023(1)°, and Z = 4.

elements.content: The dichromate ion [Cr2O7]2-, which consists of two corner-shared tetrahedra, is an attractive building block for noncentrosymmetric materials. The combination of the dichromate and [M(py)4]2+ (M = Cu, Zn) ions results in polar one-dimensional helical chains (C 1 symmetry) that are analogous to the TiO4/2O2/2 chains in potassium titanyl phosphate (KTP).

elements.content: Inherently acentric molecules can provide building blocks for the synthesis of new framework materials with possible ferroelectric and second-order nonlinear optical (NLO) behavior. The acentric oxide fluorides [NbOF5]2-, [TaOF5]2-, [WO2F4]2-, and [MoO2F4]2-  3 have been crystallized into a host of new mixed-metal materials that combine the octahedral and dinegative oxide fluoride anions with dipositive cations, typically [Cu(py)4]2+. In the primary [MX6]2- (MX6 = NbOF5, TaOF5, MoO2F4, and WO2F4) units, the displacement of the transition metal produces a noncentrosymmetric environment as well as a local polarization. The intraoctahedral distortions observed in the primary [MX6]2- units, and in KTiOPO4, LiNbO3, and other traditional materials, are compatible with the polar crystal classes 4mm(C 4 v ), 3m(C 3 v ), or mm2(C 2 v ), in which both ferroelectric and second-order NLO behavior are possible.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Inherently acentric molecules can provide building blocks for the synthesis of new framework materials with possible ferroelectric and second-order nonlinear optical (NLO) behavior. The acentric oxide fluorides [NbOF5]2-, [TaOF5]2-, [WO2F4]2-, and [MoO2F4]2-             3 have been crystallized into a host of new mixed-metal materials that combine the octahedral and dinegative oxide fluoride anions with dipositive cations, typically [Cu(py)4]2+. In the primary [MX6]2- (MX6 = NbOF5, TaOF5, MoO2F4, and WO2F4) units, the displacement of the transition metal produces a noncentrosymmetric environment as well as a local polarization. The intraoctahedral distortions observed in the primary [MX6]2- units, and in KTiOPO4, LiNbO3, and other traditional materials, are compatible with the polar crystal classes 4mm(C 4  v ), 3m(C 3  v ), or mm2(C 2  v ), in which both ferroelectric and second-order NLO behavior are possible.

elements.content: The [MO4] n - tetrahedron is another acentric building block that can be used to create noncentrosymmetric materials. For example, potassium dihydrogen phosphate is a ferroelectric material with discreet PO4 tetrahedra. The dichromate ion, [Cr2O7]2-, is another attractive candidate for study. The syntheses, structures, second harmonic signals, and infrared spectra of Cu(py)4Cr2O7, Zn(py)4Cr2O7, and Cd(py)4Cr2O7 are reported in this paper. The combination of an octahedral cation with the dichromate anion results in M(py)4Cr2O7 (M = Cu, Zn) chains similar to the TiO4/2O2/2 helices in KTiOPO4 (KTP). In KTP the short “titanyl” and long Ti−O bonds within each helical chain facilitate the large NLO response.

Experimental Section

 CAUTION. (HF) x ⋅pyridine is toxic and corrosive! 

 Materials. CuO (99.99% Aldrich), ZnO (99.99% Aldrich), CdO (99.5% Aldrich), [pyH]2[Cr2O7] (pyridinium dichromate, 98% Aldrich), pyridine (99.9% anhydrous, Aldrich), and (HF) x ⋅pyridine (pyridinium poly(hydrogen fluoride), 70% HF by weight, Aldrich) were used as received. elements.content: Synthesis. Single crystals of each of the reported compounds were synthesized by placing the appropriate amounts of reactants (see below) in Teflon (fluoro-ethylene-propylene) “pouches”. The pouches were sealed and placed in a 2000 mL autoclave filled with 600 mL of water. The autoclave was heated for 24 h at 150 °C and cooled to room temperature over an additional 24 h. The pouches were opened in air, and products were recovered by filtration.

elements.content: Cu(py) 4 Cr 2 O 7 . The compound Cu(py)4Cr2O7 was synthesized by adding 3.95 × 10-2 g (4.97 × 10-4 mol) of CuO and 1.005 × 10-1 g (2.67 × 10-4 mol) of [pyH]2[Cr2O7] to a Teflon pouch. To this mixture were added 2.067 × 10-1 g (7.85 × 10-4 mol) of (HF) x ·pyridine, 5.89 × 10-2 g (3.27 × 10-3 mol) of H2O, and 1.4937 g (1.89 × 10-2 mol) of pyridine. Green-yellow crystals were recovered in 60% yield based on copper.

Cu(py) 4 Cr 2 O 7 . Based on systematic absences and successful solution and refinement of the structure, the space group was determined to be Pna21 (No. 33). Single-crystal data were collected on a Bruker Smart CCD diffractometer. The Flack parameter was refined to determine the correct orientation of the crystal. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined using anisotropic thermal parameters. Hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized positions. Atomic coordinates for all atoms other than carbon and hydrogen are listed in Table .

Infrared Measurements. Mid-infrared (400−4000 cm-1) spectra were collected using a Bio-Rad FTS-60 FTIR spectrometer operating at a resolution of 2 cm-1.

IR data for Cu(py)4Cr2O7, KBr:  ν(py) = 1604, 639 cm-1; ν(Cr−O) = 950, 929 cm-1. IR data for Cd(py)4Cr2O7, KBr:  ν(py) = 1600, 649 cm-1; ν(Cr−O) = 950, 932 cm-1. IR data for Zn(py)4Cr2O7, KBr:  ν(py) = 1606, 640 cm-1; ν(Cr−O) = 954, 931 cm-1. The infrared bands for the dichromate anion are in good agreement with those reported for K2Cr2O7.

elements.content: Susceptibility. The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility for powdered single crystals of Cu(py)4Cr2O7 was determined with a dc superconductivity quantum interference device (SQUID) magnetometer from Quantum Design. After the powder was zero-field-cooled to 5 K, a 1 kG field was applied and the magnetic moment was registered. The magnetic moment values were calculated from the susceptibility data using the Curie−Weiss law.
elements.clean_text: Susceptibility. The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility for powdered single crystals of Cu(py)4Cr2O7 was determined  with a dc superconductivity quantum interference device (SQUID) magnetometer from Quantum Design. After the powder was zero-field-cooled to 5 K, a 1 kG field was applied and the magnetic moment was registered. The magnetic moment values were calculated from the susceptibility data using the Curie-Weiss law.

elements.content: Nonlinear Optical Measurements. Powder SHG measurements were performed on a modified Kurtz-NLO system using 1064 nm light. A Continuum Minilite II laser, operating at 15 Hz (3 mJ average energy), was used for all measurements. Ungraded SiO2, Cu(py)4Cr2O7, Cd(py)4Cr2O7, and Zn(py)4Cr2O7 were placed in separate capillary tubes. The SHG, i.e., 532 nm green light, radiation was collected in reflection and detected by a photomultiplier tube (Oriel Instruments). In order to detect only the SHG light, a 532 nm narrow band-pass interference filter was attached to the tube. A digital oscilloscope (Tektronix TDS 3032) was used to view the SHG signal.

elements.content: Cu(py) 4 Cr 2 O 7 and Zn(py) 4 Cr 2 O 7 . Cu(py)4Cr2O7 and Zn(py)4Cr2O7 are isostructural. See Figure . Bond lengths and angles for Cu(py)4Cr2O7, Zn(py)4Cr2O7, and Cd(py)4Cr2O7 are listed in Table . The nonbridging Cr−O distances in Cu(py)4Cr2O7 and Zn(py)4Cr2O7 are 1.602(4), 1.590(4), 1.569(4), and 1.599(4) Å, whereas the bridging Cr−O distances are 1.612(3), 1.777(3), 1.796(3), and 1.652(4) Å. These tetrahedra mimic the distorted phosphate tetrahedra in the ferroelectric KH2PO4 where the phosphorous ion is distorted toward an edge resulting in two long (1.56 Å) and two short (1.53 Å) bonds. The CrVI form nearly regular tetrahedra with an average O−Cr−O bond angle = 109.4° for each [Cr2O7]2-. The Cr−O−Cr bond angle deviates significantly from 180°, 134.0(2)° and 129.7(5)° for Zn(py)4Cr2O7 and Cu(py)4Cr2O7, respectively. The bond lengths and angles of the dichromate anion, in Cu(py)4Cr2O7 and Zn(py)4Cr2O7, are in good agreement with Na2Cr2O7. O(2), O(3), O(5), and O(7) exhibit large B eq's with respect to the other atoms, see Tables and . Unlike the O(1), O(4), and O(6) which are two-coordinate, these oxide ligands are only bound to one chromium center. The thermal motion of these ligands can be observed in their elongated thermal parameters.

 Cu(py)  4  Cr  2  O  7   and Zn(py)  4  Cr  2  O  7  . Cu(py)4Cr2O7 and Zn(py)4Cr2O7 are isostructural. See Figure . Bond lengths and angles for Cu(py)4Cr2O7, Zn(py)4Cr2O7, and Cd(py)4Cr2O7 are listed in Table . The nonbridging Cr-O distances in Cu(py)4Cr2O7 and Zn(py)4Cr2O7 are 1.602(4), 1.590(4), 1.569(4), and 1.599(4) Å, whereas the bridging Cr-O distances are 1.612(3), 1.777(3), 1.796(3), and 1.652(4) Å. These tetrahedra mimic the distorted phosphate tetrahedra in the ferroelectric KH2PO4 where the phosphorous ion is distorted toward an edge resulting in two long (1.56 Å) and two short (1.53 Å) bonds. The CrVI form nearly regular tetrahedra with an average O-Cr-O bond angle = 109.4° for each [Cr2O7]2-. The Cr-O-Cr bond angle deviates significantly from 180°, 134.0(2)° and 129.7(5)° for Zn(py)4Cr2O7 and Cu(py)4Cr2O7, respectively. The bond lengths and angles of the dichromate anion, in Cu(py)4Cr2O7 and Zn(py)4Cr2O7, are in good agreement with Na2Cr2O7. O(2), O(3), O(5), and O(7) exhibit large B eq's with respect to the other atoms, see Tables  and . Unlike the O(1), O(4), and O(6) which are two-coordinate, these oxide ligands are only bound to one chromium center. The thermal motion of these ligands can be observed in their elongated thermal parameters.

The cations consist of a central Cu2+ or Zn2+ cation with four pyridine rings in a square planar arrangement. The axially distorted Jahn−Teller Cu2+ cations contain four “short” equatorial bonds to pyridine (2.039(3), 2.030(3), 2.029(2), 2.025(2) Å) and two “long” axial bonds to oxygen (2.296(2) and 2.320(2) Å). The spherical Zn2+ cation, as expected, bonds to four pyridine rings through lengths of 2.138(4), 2.157(5), 2.151(4), and 2.141(4) Å, while the Zn−O bond lengths are 2.109(4) and 2.152(3) Å.

elements.content: Cd(py) 4 Cr 2 O 7 . Crystallographic disorder in the [Cr2O7]2- anion results in the superimposition of two orientations upon one another as shown in Figure . The ligands O(1) and O(2) are common to both orientations, while the remaining two ligands in each tetrahedron consist of either O(3) and O(6), or O(4) and O(5). O(3) and O(6) exhibit abnormally large B eq'swith respect to the other atoms, suggesting an unequal population of the two disorder orientations. However, O(2) is constrained to occupy two sites equally, eliminating in this model and space group the possibility of O(3) and O(6) having less than 1/2 occupancy.

elements.content: Nonlinear Optical Measurements. The second-order NLO properties of Cu(py)4Cr2O7, Zn(py)4Cr2O7, and Cd(py)4Cr2O7 were measured using the Kurtz powder technique. Zn(py)4Cr2O7 exhibited a signal comparable to α-quartz under the same conditions. No signal was observed for Cu(py)4Cr2O7 owing to absorption of the incident beam. No signal was observed for Cd(py)4Cr2O7 because this compound crystallizes in a centrosymmetric space group.

elements.content: The presence of a nonspherical Jahn−Teller active cation, Cu2+, affects the unit cell dimensions of M(py)4Cr2O7 (M = Cu, Zn) with respect to Zn2+. The elongation of the Jahn−Teller axis in Cu(py)4Cr2O7 results in an increase in the unit cell parameters b and c, 16.324(3) and 8.857(2) Å in Cu(py)4Cr2O7 versus 16.005(1) and 8.8130(5) Å in Zn(py)4Cr2O7 because the one-dimensional chains run in the direction of the b and c axes. The unit cell parameter a, which runs perpendicular to the one-dimensional chains, is longer in the Zn analogue than in the Cu analogue because the average Zn−N bond distance, 2.14(1) Å, is greater than that of the Cu−N bond, 2.04(1) Å.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

The presence of a nonspherical Jahn-Teller active cation, Cu2+, affects the unit cell dimensions of M(py)4Cr2O7 (M = Cu, Zn) with respect to Zn2+. The elongation of the Jahn-Teller axis in Cu(py)4Cr2O7 results in an increase in the unit cell parameters b and c, 16.324(3) and 8.857(2) Å in Cu(py)4Cr2O7 versus 16.005(1) and 8.8130(5) Å in Zn(py)4Cr2O7 because the one-dimensional chains run in the direction of the b and c axes. The unit cell parameter a, which runs perpendicular to the one-dimensional chains, is longer in the Zn analogue than in the Cu analogue because the average Zn-N bond distance, 2.14(1) Å, is greater than that of the Cu-N bond, 2.04(1) Å.

elements.content: The structures of M(py)4Cr2O7 (M = Cu, Zn) and KTP7 share several striking similarities. KTP consists of helical TiO4/2O2/2 chains linked by phosphate tetrahedra. Each layer, composed of parallel chains, is rotated 90° every a/2. The M(py)4Cr2O7 (M = Cu, Zn) chains also pack in this fashion. Figure shows the common structural themes in M(py)4Cr2O7 (M = Cu, Zn) and KTP. The TiO4/2O2/2 chains in KTP contain two types of TiO4/2O2/2 octahedra, either a cis or trans orientation of the bridging oxygens with respect to one another. The cis and trans coordinated TiO4/2O2/2 octahedra are replaced by [M(py)4]2+ (M = Cu, Zn) and [Cr2O7]2- respectively in M(py)4Cr2O7 (M = Cu, Zn). The TiO4/2O2/2 and M(py)4Cr2O7 (M = Cu, Zn) chains are shown in Figure .

elements.content: With the similarities some differences also exist. The length of each rotation in the M(py)4Cr2O7 (M = Cu, Zn) chains, 18.57 and 18.27 Å, respectively, is longer than the corresponding TiO4/2O2/2 rotation, 12.40 Å. Also, in M(py)4Cr2O7 (M = Cu, Zn) the chains are not covalently bound to one another, van der Waals forces support the structure, while in KTP phosphate tetrahedra connect the nonintersecting TiO4/2O2/2 chains.

elements.content: Kurtz powder experiments on Zn(py)4Cr2O7 demonstrate the second-order NLO properties inherent to the polar space group Pna21. No second-order signal was observed from Cu(py)4Cr2O7 owing to absorption of the incident radiation by the powder. Zn(py)4Cr2O7, however, suffers from no such problems and the SHG signal at 532 nm was measured. Cd(py)4Cr2O7 crystallizes in the space group C2/c (No. 15). This space group is indistinguishable from Cc (No. 9) based on systematic absences. If Cd(py)4Cr2O7 crystallized in Cc, no disorder in the [Cr2O7]2- anion would be expected and the compound would exhibit second-order NLO properties. The centrosymmetric disorder model is consistent with the null result from SHG test. If the compound crystallizes in Cc, the noncentrosymmetric space group, a positive second-order NLO result is expected because no absorption was encountered in Zn(py)4Cr2O7, a compound with similar optical properties.

elements.content: The combination of the two molecular ions, [Cr2O7]2- and [M(py)4]2+ (M = Cd, Cu, Zn), and subsequent crystallization at 150 °C has resulted in three new transition metal oxides, two of which crystallize in the polar space group Pna21. The noncentrosymmetric phases M‘(py)4Cr2O7 (M‘ = Cu, Zn) consist of one-dimensional chains that are quite similar to the TiO4/2O2/2 helical chains in KTP. The use of corner-shared tetrahedral anions to enforce acentricity upon a metal oxide chain is a novel strategy for the discovery of new noncentrosymmetric, polar materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The combination of the two molecular ions, [Cr2O7]2- and [M(py)4]2+ (M = Cd, Cu, Zn), and subsequent crystallization at 150 °C has resulted in three new transition metal oxides, two of which crystallize in the polar space group Pna21. The noncentrosymmetric phases M‘(py)4Cr2O7 (M‘ = Cu, Zn) consist of one-dimensional chains that are quite similar to the TiO4/2O2/2 helical chains in KTP. The use of corner-shared tetrahedral anions to enforce acentricity upon a metal oxide chain is a novel strategy for the discovery of new noncentrosymmetric, polar materials.

cln_elements.content:
Cu(py) 4 Cr 2 O 7 . The compound Cu(py)4Cr2O7 was synthesized by adding 3.95 × 10-2 g (4.97 × 10-4 mol) of CuO and 1.005 × 10-1 g (2.67 × 10-4 mol) of [pyH]2[Cr2O7] to a Teflon pouch. To this mixture were added 2.067 × 10-1 g (7.85 × 10-4 mol) of (HF) x ·pyridine, 5.89 × 10-2 g (3.27 × 10-3 mol) of H2O, and 1.4937 g (1.89 × 10-2 mol) of pyridine. Green-yellow crystals were recovered in 60% yield based on copper.

Zn(py) 4 Cr 2 O 7 . The compound Zn(py)4Cr2O7 was synthesized by adding 5.28 × 10-2 g (6.57 × 10-4 mol) of ZnO and 1.04 × 10-1 g (2.76 × 10-4 mol) of [pyH]2[Cr2O7] to a Teflon pouch. To this mixture were added 1.91 × 10-1 g (7.23 × 10-4 mol) of (HF) x ·pyridine, 7.25 × 10-2 g (4.03 × 10-3 mol) of H2O, and 1.578 g (1.997 × 10-2 mol) of pyridine. Orange crystals were recovered in 50% yield based on zinc.

Cd(py) 4 Cr 2 O 7 . The compound Cd(py)4Cr2O7 was synthesized by adding 4.45 × 10-2 g (3.47 × 10-4 mol) of CdO and 1.005 × 10-1 g (2.67 × 10-4 mol) of [pyH]2[Cr2O7] to a Teflon “pouch”. To this mixture were added 1.76 × 10-1 g (6.67 × 10-4 mol) of (HF) x ·pyridine, 5.21 × 10-2 g (2.89 × 10-3 mol) of H2O, and 1.503 g (1.902 × 10-2 mol) of pyridine. Orange crystals were recovered in 60% yield based on cadmium.
